header.title: Nick Ferrari savages ‘breathtakingly arrogant’ Remainer who called Brexiteers 'uneducated'
header.subtitle: NICK FERRARI was stunned when an LBC caller made the “breathtakingly arrogant” claim that people who voted for Brexit were “ill-informed, uneducated and gullible”.
header.postText: LBC host Nick Ferrari spoke to Caller Peter on his radio show after a revelation from Nigel Farage. The Brexit Party leader claimed that Conservatives were offering his candidates jobs to get them to stand down. Peter attacked Mr Farage as a predator, and also told Mr Ferrari that by voting leave, he was in league with every single racist in the country.', 'Peter said: People like Nigel Farage, they prey on the ill-informed, uneducated and gullible.   ', '   The LBC host immediately snapped back that Peter had been so rude to 17.4 million people.   ', '   However,   the caller insisted: Not all of them knew what they were voting for. The reality is even you didn't know what you were voting for.', 'You voted for Brexit on a basis of racism in Eastern Europe, and still ended up on the same side of the argument as every other racist in Britain.',    Mr Ferrari shot back: I really enjoy our conversations,   but actually that is breathtakingly arrogant of you to tell me I didn 't know what I was voting for., '   I would never say that to you, I would never say that to anyone. That, respectfully, is so arrogant.', '   How can you honestly tell me I didn 't know what I was voting for? Really?',   'Peter tried to defend his claim by referring back to past words of the radio host.',   'He said: I'   ve heard your passionate speech about the reasons you 've voted for Brexit.',   But if you would look a bit deeper, you would realise that you casted your vote in order to combat racism in Eastern Europe because you didn't want to be a part of the countries which has too many racists.,   'You have too many racists in all countries around the world, not just in Eastern Europe, but in Britain as well. You voted the same way that every single racist in the country voted.',   'Mr Ferrari was less than impressed: You<99>re now saying that effectively every single person who voted to leave is a racist.',   'I<99>m sure you<99>re a good bloke, and if I met you on Wimbledon high street, I<99>m sure we<99>d get on and have a cup of coffee.',   Please consider your language, this is exactly what we don't need at this time.,   'Everyone who voted to leave is not a racist, Peter.',   'I think we<99>ve had this argument respectfully.

commentThread.commentText: There is not right or wrong answer. People’s choice to vote one way or the other was a matter of personal opinion, so it is pointless arguing about it. Leave received more votes and legislation was passed. Leaving the EU bloc is now law and it must be allowed to progress unhindered. Remainers, and particularly the LibDems, are obstructing the passage of this law and should be dealt with accordingly.

Sadly, this kind of language and argument is common with Remainers. I have heard it so many times now, it has become boring. There are a multitude of reasons people voted to Leave, but they ALL knew why they voted Leave. Maybe we should ask wh y Remainers voted the way they did, because I have heard some pitiful reasons over the last three years , including " Not being able to travel to Europe " . " Not being able to work abroad " " Destruction of the UK economy " The list was endless, and mostly worthless. If any one didn't know what they were voting for, I would say it was t he Remainers out there.

replies.commentText: I'm a bit of an "agnostic" on the subject of Brexit. I don't have very strong feelings either way, but based on my observations the arguments for Brexit, as put forward by Nigel Farage, developed over time from one of just seeking an "arm's length" relationship with the EU, I believed he argued for a Norway-like agreement with membership of the EEA. This appeared not to resonate with th e Brexit leaning population and so was further developed into more of an anti-emigration argument. This had the desired result, based on the referendum outcome. It does, however, make it difficult f or Brexit supporters to put forward arguments wider than this narrow subject.

Immigration was certainly a factor, but most see it as a problem as it is not controlled from the EU. That might not be seen as a problem, depending on where you live and your prospect of finding decent employment, as it is a recognised cause of wage suppression in many areas. Not where I live, but in the North of the country that is a problem. Saying it's difficult to widen the argument is not true.  Personally I don't want to be a part of a United States of Europe, and I have never wanted to be in anything other than the Trading Partnership we went into in the 1970's.  I also believe the UK is being used as a Bank to support other member countries, that are milking the system.  The recent flooding of Venice is a prime example of corruption in Italy. The flood defences have been hindered by it, and the Political weakness in the country.
